recommendations.recommendation: Nice anime. Great story but the drawing is only half goog. The live action is the best. Great for sport fans
Terrible art. unlikable characters, choppy animation. and a story that has been done better in most sport anime. only for fans

The ping pong The animation anime team has done something truly amazing. They took a story that would be other wise boring and completely deviated from today`s animation standard and made a complete masterpiece in 11 episodes. At first I was very skeptical of how good a sports anime would be with only 11 episodes, but they sure know how to tell a story.
That`s the selling point of this anime; the storytelling and execution were incredible.
More than a anime about table tennis, this is a story about change, moving on, giving it your all, friendship, and the hardships that come with them.
Truly a beautiful piece of work.
Recommended to anyone who enjoys all kinds of anime, those people who can see a diamond before it is a diamond.
Great storyline and nice ending. Animation is unique and fits to the story. Love the music.

This can be place among best anime series.. The art style, animation, character design as well as overall directions has been done in superb way.. If you have not watched it yet then watch it. you won`t regret it..

another great work by taiyou matsumoto. his unmistakeable style (just like in tekkon kinkreet) may seem weird at first but it can grow on you, especially since it`s a welcome change from the usual monotony. unlike the unnecessary superficial mainstream bullshit, this show is pure and actually watchable even though the theme is table tennis. i haven`t felt that way about an anime for a long time. check it out if you`re tired of being fed shitty plots with cliche characters, big guns, explosions and almost naked chicks (there`s porn for that). with one outs, detroit metal city and eve no jikan, 2008 was the last year with any bearable material, when 2007 had kaiji, sword of the stranger, byousoku 5 centimeter and nodame cantabile. 2006 had bartender, DEATH NOTE, ergo proxy, tekkon kinkreet. the further you go into the past - the more good stuff you find. lately every anime`s categories include: action, ecchi, harem, big breasts, martial arts, pantsu. i don`t watch that shit.

One of the best animes to be released in YEARS, if not ever. Seriously. As a whole, this anime is bordering on perfect. It is dense, emotional, heart-pounding intense at times, GORGEOUS to watch, metaphorical, literal, existential, realist.
The hyper-stylized animation is seriously gorgeous, and rich with vivid imagery and cutaways between the immaculate action sequences (ping pong matches) and intriguing, well-developed character drama.
The protagonists are deep, wounded, and struggling. They are real human beings, struggling with self-doubt, fear, repressed memories, aspirations, limitations, devastating failure, and empty triumph.
This anime, despite the surreal animation, feels so. Genuinely. Real.
This will be the first anime I ever buy on blu-ray when it is released, and probably one of the first anime on my list when I recommend shows to people looking to get into anime themselves.
Watch it. It will change something in you.

This show was the biggest positive surprise of 2014 for me. A totally unique anime, which focuses on character development and not so much on Ping Pong or table tennis as the title suggests. The sport is just a vehicle for friendship, rivalry, emotions and character growth. One of the best parts is the realistic ending.
It is much more than a sport anime. It is epic, pure, and brilliant. Get out of your comfort zone and give this one a shot.
A Full package, fantastic direction, soundtrack, animation and characters. Easily one of the best series ive ever seen.

This is a really fun and original sports anime unlike any I`ve seen before, but that`s not a bad thing. Very unique animation style that has to be seen. Voice work is top notch and characters are interesting. Definitely one of the top new shows of spring 2014.

A truly interesting sports anime despite only with 11 episodes. Its relatively fast paced indeed and it doesn`t serve up an over complicated plot points.
Some say in terms of art and animation, its poorly executed. The art is simply refreshing and different to me. Probably its not as drastic as you think though. That`s why, it does have effect of realism and weirdness in the art. Thus, it has an unique animation style.
In short, the story is a little deeper about talent and the desire to overcome one of the sports out there, especially table tennis. The character development are very intriguing although it feels like one-dimensional. I do like the way they portrayed along the ride. Such a realistic human being drama.
In the end, the fans definitely will find something an enjoyable and entertaining out of this show.
Quite possibly the greatest coming-of-age and sports anime ever produced, and is a perfect length of 11 episodes so it can be watched easily in under 5 hours

I don`t like ping pong, but gosh darn it, ping pong has never been so good!
Ping Pong has a certain charm about it that many anime lack which makes it really compelling to watch, and very enjoyable and satisfying in the long run, mainly thanks to its great directing by Yuasa Masaaki.
And this isn`t just about ping pong, but also about the characters and their journey to come in terms with themselves, which serves as great development, which gives it an edge over the majority of all sports anime out there.
Apart from feeling a tad shorter than what it could`ve been, it`s a satisfying story with a satisfying ending - it`s a definite must see.

Great anime. Everything is impeccably done: beautiful story, very good character development (especially when the anime is only this short), fitting modern soundtrack. The animation is very unique, some might find it offputting but when lately almost every anime is animated the same, this feels refreshing.
It is about ping pong, but you shouldn`t put it in the same category as sports-shounens. This one doesn`t rely on the old archetypical story where everything is cliche. It is completely unique.

Yuasa Masaaki is quickly becoming one of my favorite anime directors, once again showcasing his unique and interesting style in Ping Pong the Animation. In this series—like many previous titles—he`s working together with Itou Nobutake, and the result is just outstanding.
The amazing part about Ping Pong is it`s ability to take an unoriginal, simple story and make it something fresh and exciting. The incredible artwork, interesting characterization and engaging direction can`t be described as anything less than masterful.
Personally I`m not too happy about the state of anime in 2014 but this is the kind of series that keeps my hope up. I`m definitely looking forward to seeing more of Yuasa and I`m hoping that he`ll continue to work with Itou in the future.

anime.description: Two long-time friends http://anidb.net/ch65254 [Smile] and http://anidb.net/ch65253 [Peco] are both members of the ping pong club at their high school and are both very talented at the sport. However, Smile`s quiet personality keeps him from being able to win against Peco. The club`s teacher takes notice of Smile`s talent and works to change his attitude toward the sport. Source: ANN

tag.name: maintenance tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: seinen
tag.description: Seinen, literally "young man", is one of the main demographic classifications applied to manga, and, by extension, to anime, especially manga-based ones. As the name implies, seinen works are marketed primarily to an audience of young men; the age range commonly understood to be the target of such works goes roughly from 17 to somewhere in the 40s.

tag.name: high school
tag.description: A secondary school that usually contains grades 10 through 12 in Japan, or 9 through 12 in America.

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: present
tag.description: Somewhere between past and future.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: school clubs
tag.description: Even though school clubs in Japan are not mandatory, there is some pressure from the social grid (e.g. fellow students, teachers) to participate in some kind of after-school activity, be it in sports or arts. Colleges also have clubs. As a comedy element in anime, some students have joined too many clubs, and are thus constantly stressed out. There is also the element of social commentary, making it clear that you have to join a club, if you want to be part of the class. Since self-founded clubs need at least 3 members, the desperate search and advertising for new members can be cause for hilarity in anime.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Japan is a sovereign island nation in East Asia. Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies off the eastern coast of the Asian mainland and stretches from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and China in the southwest. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: unrequited love
tag.description: At least one character has a romantic interest in another one, but the feelings are not returned. This is the cornerstone of all love triangles or love polygons.

tag.name: plot continuity
tag.description: Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer. A single linear focused plot is highly continuous. A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is Earth`s largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth`s total land area and 8.7% of the Earth`s total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: friendship
tag.description: The feeling of trust, kindness, and friendship between a group of high school students for example, is a central theme of this anime.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: sports
tag.description: Sports anime revolves around a recreational physical activity or skill. In addition they often adhere to certain genre conventions, the emphasis on training and practice in preparation for competition, characters desire for self improvement, and pursuit of a specific goal.

tag.name: coming of age
tag.description: In the strict sense the Coming of age describes a young person`s transition from adolescence to adulthood. In anime the term is used in a more general sense where the protagonists have to face a challenge, make an important decision in their life, take on responsibility, or learn a lesson, and by overcoming these obstacles they reach a higher level of maturity.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: aim for the top
tag.description: This can be a positive or negative plot device. A character may strive to become the best in an altruistic way (e.g. best healer, most widely learned master), or it can be quite banal and primitive (e.g. challenged delinquents wanting to be the strongest fighters). Alas in fighting anime the latter usually prevails.

tag.name: male protagonist
tag.description: This anime has a male protagonist.

tag.name: table tennis
tag.description: Table tennis (also called ping pong) is a sport in which two or four players hit a lightweight ball back and forth using a table tennis racket. The game takes place on a hard table divided by a net. Except for the initial serve, players must allow a ball played toward them only one bounce on their side of the table and must return it so that it bounces on the opposite side. Points are scored when a player fails to return the ball within the rules. Play is fast and demands quick reactions. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: experimental animation
tag.description: This anime uses distinct, alternative animation — much unlike other contemporary anime — either throughout or in individual episodes/sequences.

tag.name: bullying
tag.description: Bullying is the use of force, threat, or coercion to abuse, intimidate, or aggressively dominate others. One who engages in bullying is known as a bully. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: training
tag.description: Training is extensive, serious practising a person undergoes in order to develop skills and abilities, such as handling weapons, playing instruments, playing sports, and so on.

tag.name: competition
tag.description: Some sort of confrontation occurs in this show. The protagonists "duke it out" via various competitions.

tag.name: noitaminA
tag.description: noitaminA (ノイタミナ) – Animation written backwards – is a Fuji Television programming block, devoted to anime, broadcast each Thursday night from 00:45 to 1:15. It was launched with the intention of expanding the target audience beyond the typical young male demographic. The timeslot was expanded from half an hour to a full hour in 2010, and now airs Thursday nights from 00:45 to 1:45. noitaminA aired its first non-anime series in 2010, with the premiere of the live-action adaptation of Moyashimon. On April 15, 2010, Fuji TV and FUNimation announced an agreement that allows FUNimation to simulcast series from the noitaminA block in North America within an hour of their airing in Japan.

tag.name: flashback
tag.description: A flashback is a moment in which someone remembers events from their past. In fiction, flashbacks are used primarily to give insight into a character`s mind or to reveal information which had been previously kept from the audience. They normally consist essentially of new content; in some cases, they may also consist of short snippets of already displayed content, as in http://anidb.net/ch23266 [Okabe Rintarou]`s flashbacks in http://anidb.net/a7729 [Steins;Gate], but even in these cases the flashbacks are used to look into what the character is thinking. As such, they are different from and should not be confused with recaps, which are old content being shown again for no particular purpose other than padding or reminding the audience of the events up to that point. As a rule of thumb, to qualify as a flashback, the scene must advance the show`s content in some way or form; anything else is just a recap.

tag.name: motivational anime
tag.description: The anime motivates doing something which is shown in the show (for example club activity, sports, choosing a job, a hobby etc).

tag.name: time skip
tag.description: The plot features at least one skip or jump in time. Example: A skip from the present into the past, or time skips in increments, e.g. every hour there is a time skip by a day.

tag.name: tournament
tag.description: A competition involving a large number of participants. Such competitions may range from friendly, moderated sporting events to anything-goes, all-out fights to the death. All participants take part in the tournament in want or need of the final goal and possible prizes; which depending on genre, may range from a boastful record at school to great riches and/or the granting of a wish. Depending on the type of tournament, contestants will either act alone, be permitted a team, or construct a team of chance throughout the ongoing competition.

tag.name: following one`s dream
tag.description: No matter what the hardships may be, at least one of the protagonists in this anime is following her/his dream. Examples: To become a professional athlete, a musician, a painter or the ruler of this world!

tag.name: predominantly male cast
tag.description: The anime features a mostly male cast, i.e. female characters are rare. Example: Reverse harem setting with a plethora of bishounen.

tag.name: rivalry
tag.description: Quite broadly used term describing a conflict, contest, struggle, or opposition of some sort. Typical examples: The mostly comedic rivalry for the love of a protagonist in a harem anime (love polygon), the more "mindless" battles between wannabe delinquents in a school fighting anime, or the struggle between good & evil in an epic conflict for world domination.

tag.name: childhood memory
tag.description: The childhood memory of one of the protagonists plays an important part as plot device in this anime.

tag.name: mundane made awesome
tag.description: Sometimes normal just doesn`t cut it. Eating: you put food in your mouth and chew. Playing sports: you throw a ball around. You need to make it awesome, no matter how mundane it is. Let`s throw in some gripping orchestral music, lighting changes, different camera angles, something! Don`t write like a man, write like an evil overlord! Exaggerate your expressions and gestures, speak with excessive intonation, and if all else fails, throw in some close-ups, slow motion, and ominous Latin chanting! With practice, even you can turn something like eating chips into an epic battle of light and dark, blinding the viewer with sheer awesomeness. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: Engrish
tag.description: Engrish is actually a mispronunciation of English, as can be the result of someone, who does not have English as their primary language of origin (such as Japanese or Chinese). Occasionally characters in the original Japanese dialogue version of an anime will speak in English... however; this often still requires the assistance of subtitles, for while the words are meant to be said in English, the sentence structure and letter pronunciation may still be strongly related to the person’s primary language.

tag.name: the power of love
tag.description: The power of love is not only the strongest power known to mankind, it is the strongest power in the universe. The power of love conquers all things. It makes people cry, it makes people laugh, it can make them sing and occasionally it even brings dead people back to life, just so. More so than the power of friendship, the power of true love gives boundless strength and resolution; by the power of love every hardship can be overcome, every issue can be resolved and it does make people resistant to food poisoning (caused by the bad cooking of their loved ones). Even the big bad evil doesn`t stand a chance against the power of true love and often ends up redeemed. Even when the power of love is not literally and directly responsible, the scene is often set so that the audience is left with the impression that it was "really responsible".

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO EPISODE
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to episode tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what episodes they should be assigned to.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: multi-anime projects
tag.description: Many anime are created as part of larger projects encompassing many shows without direct relation to one another. Normally, there is a specific idea in mind: for example, the http://anidb.net/t4859 [Young Animator Training Project] aims to stimulate the on-the-job training of next-generation professionals of the anime industry, whereas the http://anidb.net/t3763 [World Masterpiece Theatre] aims to animate classical stories from all over the world.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: adapted into Japanese movie
tag.description: This anime is a http://anidb.net/t2797 [new original work], and it has been adapted into a Japanese movie. In exceedingly rare instances, a specific episode of a new original work anime can also be adapted.

tag.name: adapted into other media
tag.description: This anime is a http://anidb.net/t2797 [new original work], and it has been adapted into other media formats. In exceedingly rare instances, a specific episode of a new original work anime can also be adapted.

episode.title: 風の音がジャマをしている
The Wind Makes It Too Hard to Hear
Le bruit du vent nous gène
Kaze no Oto ga Jama o Shiteiru
episode.summary: Spring. The Hatase High school gymnasium. Table tennis club adviser Koizumi Jo notices a cut-man with glasses on the team. He is one of the up-and-comers who joined the team this year, Tsukimoto Makoto (Smile). Meanwhile, the other up-and-comer Hoshino Yutaka (Peco) is swindling a man at Obaba`s Tamura Table Tennis Hall. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 絶対に負けない唯一の方法は闘わない事だ
The Only Way to Be Sure You Won`t Lose Is to Not Fight
La seule façon de ne pas perdre, c`est de ne pas jouer
Zettai ni Makenai Yuitsu no Houhou wa Tatakawanai Koto Da
episode.summary: Smile loses his match against Smile. After watching the game, Koizumi expresses his rage, saying, "A guy who doesn`t even want to win shouldn`t treat the game like a joke!" Seeing his fury, Obaba asks Koizumi if Smile reminds him of himself 50 years ago. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 卓球に人生をかけるなんて気味が悪い
Staking Your Life On Table Tennis Is Revolting
C`est effrayant de sacrifier sa vie pour le ping pong
Takkyuu ni Jinsei o Kakeru Nante Kimi ga Warui
episode.summary: The Inter-High preliminaries begin as though swallowing the hopes of every player. If Peco defeats his noisy quarterfinal opponent, he`ll remain in the top 4 and advance to nationals. Peco`s quarterfinal opponent is Sakuma AKA "Akuma". Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: スマイルはロボット
Smile Is a Robot
Smile, le robot
Smile wa Robot
episode.summary: Peco is shocked when he gets skunked by "China" a.k.a. Kong Wenge. Meanwhile, Koizumi tells Smile not to play with Peco anymore. Koizumi instructs Smile to overcome his lack of competitive spirit by the Inter High. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: おまえ誰より卓球好きじゃんよ!!
You Love This Sport More Than Anyone!!
Tu aimes le ping-pong plus que quiconque !!
Omae Dare yori Takkyuu Suki Jan yo!!
episode.summary: Having quit table tennis, Peco hangs around Tamura Table Tennis Hall eating snacks. Meanwhile, Smile polishes his skills with Koizumi in order to win, causing discord between himself and his teammates. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: どこで間違えた?
Where Did I Go Wrong?
Où ai-je fait une erreur ?
Doko de Machigaeta?
episode.summary: After winning the Inter-High, Dragon goes on to win the Junior Olympics singles, and makes his triumphant return. At a press conference after his return, Dragon clearly states Kaio`s need for players on Tsukimoto`s level. Dragon`s statement creates subtle waves in the Kaio Academy team. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ヒーロー見参
The Hero Appears
Que le héros apparaisse
Hero Kenzan
episode.summary: Peco practices among college students at the training center in preparation for the Inter-High preliminaries. When Koizumi learns from Obaba that Peco is still playing table tennis, he registers Peco for the event. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: イエス マイコーチ
Yes, My Coach
Yes, my coach
Yes, My Coach
episode.summary: Smile is finally scouted by Kaio. Dragon declares, "Keep playing in this dumpy environment and your talent will rot." After attempting to persuade Smile, as Dragon heads home, he recalls painful memories from his past. Meanwhile, Peco decides to make a comeback and Obaba works him hard. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 血は鉄の味がする
Blood Tastes Like Iron
Le sang a le goût du fer
Chi wa Tetsu no Aji ga Suru
episode.summary: Relentlessly working his injured knee, Peco beats Dragon. The upset sends shock running through the gymnasium. The final match pits Katase High`s Peco against Smile. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ヒーローなのだろうが!!
I Thought You Were the Hero!!
Je croyais que tu étais un héros
Hero na no Darou ga!!
episode.summary: Peco and Dragon`s match is about to begin. Dragon is surprised when he handles Peco`s racket. Peco dauntlessly smiles and tells Dragon he bought it to play with him. It is a reverse penhold racket. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 少し泣く
Gonna Cry a Bit
Je vais pleurer un peu
Sukoshi Naku
episode.summary: Peco beats China. However, the defeated China felt refreshed. Joining Smile, the new Peco who appeared on Katase High`s team becomes the talk of the town in the blink of an eye. While rumors of Kaio`s crisis run out of control, Dragon recalls his father while in the bathroom. Source: crunchyroll
